DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Government Declares State of Emergency
DOC.UNK: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with reports Ceausescu may be leaving the country, more on protests in Bucharest. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Romania's embattled leadership declared a state of emergency Friday as a popular revolt spread throughout the country, Yugoslavia's official Tanjug news agency reported from Bucharest. Tanjug's report said the situation in the country that President Nicolae Ceausescu has ruled with an iron fist for 24 years was ``dramatic.'' Some reports said Ceausescu was preparing to flee the country. Troops reportedly killed at least 13 people in Bucharest on Thursday in a crackdown on thousands of demonstrators who jeered a speech by Ceausescu. Various news agencies said Defense Minister Vasile Milea had committed suicide. The British Broadcasting Corp. said he had blamed himself for the nationwide unrest that was touched off by the weekend massacre of hundreds of protesters in the western city of Timisoara. New protests reportedly occurred in Bucharest Friday morning, and Tanjug said security forces opened fire. There were no reports of casualties. Tanjug said protesters began gathering at 9:00 a.m. in the capital, chanting ``join us, join us,'' as they marched through the streets. Later Friday, the Bulgarian state news agency BTA reported from Bucharest that the army had withdrawn from the streets and that soldiers were ``fraternizing with the people.'' It said that all police in front of the Intercontinental Hotel _ the scene of protests Thursday _ had withdrawn. The massive unrest, reported in at least eight cities, indicated Romanians have been caught up in the pro-democracy movements sweeping Eastern Europe and are no longer willing to tolerate Ceausescu's repression and the harships he has forced on them. There were reports of a general strike in Timisoara and similarly unconfirmed reports that a major factory in Bucharest which employs some 20,000 people had gone on strike on Friday. Austrian television quoted Romanian exiles as saying Ceausescu could possibly be leaving the country and heading for exile in China. Western reports, citing witness accounts, said planes were seen being loaded at Bucharest airport with goods, indicating Ceausescu and his family could be preparing to leave. Ceausescu declared a state of emergency in the Timisoara region late Wednesday, but the nationwide declaration indicated the unrest had spread to other parts of the country. Romanian Television announced a special program on Friday and radio was playing military music, Hungarian Radio said. A presidential decree said the state of emergency was necessary because of ``the serious violation of public order through terrorist acts, vandalism and destruction of public assets,'' the BBC said, quoting Hungarian Radio.
